articles.title: Celebrating 25 Years of Humanity in Space
articles.summary: In 2025, NASA and its international partners celebrate 25 years of continuous human presence aboard the International Space Station. Since November 2, 2000, more than 290 people from 26 countries have lived and worked aboard the orbiting laboratory, conducting thousands of experiments that have advanced science and technology on Earth and paved the way for […]
articles.content:
NASA astronaut Jonny Kim poses for a portrait with the American flag inside the International Space Station’s “window to the world,” the cupola. NASA

In 2025, NASA and its international partners celebrate 25 years of continuous human presence aboard the International Space Station. Since November 2, 2000, more than 290 people from 26 countries have lived and worked aboard the orbiting laboratory, conducting thousands of experiments that have advanced science and technology on Earth and paved the way for Artemis missions to the Moon and future journeys to Mars.

Beyond its role as a science platform, the station has been a bridge—connecting cultures, sparking creativity, and inspiring generations. The memories of Johnson Space Center employees reflect how the orbiting laboratory is not only an engineering marvel but also a deeply human endeavor.

Christopher Brown – Advancing Life Support Systems for Future Exploration

Christopher Brown (center) receives the Rotary National Award for Space Achievement alongside NASA astronaut Sunita Williams. NASA/James Blair

As a space station Environmental Control and Life Support System (ECLSS) integrator, Christopher Brown’s role has been ensuring astronauts have clean air and water. ECLSS removes carbon dioxide from the air, supplies oxygen for breathing, and recycles wastewater—turning yesterday’s coffee into tomorrow’s coffee. Today, these systems can recover nearly 98% of the water brought to the station.

His proudest memory was commissioning regenerative life support systems and raising a symbolic toast with the crew while on console in mission control. He also helped activate the Water Storage System, saving crew time and improving operations on station. For Brown, these milestones were vital steps toward future long-duration missions beyond Earth.

Stephanie Sipila – The Heart of Microgravity Research

NASA astronaut Kate Rubins works on the Cardinal Heart study, which seeks to help scientists understand the aging and weakening of heart muscles in the search for new treatments for astronauts and people on Earth. NASA/Mike Hopkins

Stephanie Sipila, now integration manager for NASA’s Extravehicular Activity and Human Surface Mobility Program, began her career as a mechanical and robotic systems instructor for the orbital outpost. Her favorite experiment, Engineered Heart Tissues, studies microgravity’s effect on the human heart to help develop new treatments for cardiovascular disease. She recalls NASA astronaut Sunita Williams running the Boston Marathon on a treadmill aboard station, becoming the first person to complete the race in space and showing how astronauts stay connected to Earth while living on orbit.

Sipila also highlights the Spacesuit Art Project, an initiative that turned artwork from children with cancer into spacesuits flown to and worn aboard the orbital outpost during live downlinks, connecting science, art, and hope — and raising awareness of cancer research conducted aboard the orbital outpost.

Liz Warren – Where Exploration Meets Humanity

NASA astronaut Jack Fischer wearing the Unity spacesuit painted by patients at MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. NASA/Randy Bresnik

Space station Associate Chief Scientist Liz Warren has seen firsthand how the Spacesuit Art Project uplifted children on Earth. During Expedition 52, she watched astronaut Jack Fischer wear a suit covered in artwork created by young cancer patients, including his own daughter, a survivor. “It was incredibly touching to note the power of art and inspiration. Human spaceflight requires fortitude, resilience, and teamwork—so does fighting childhood cancer,” Warren said.

Her memories also extend to her time as an operations lead for NASA’s Human Research Program, which uses research to develop methods to protect the health and performance of astronauts in space to prepare for long-duration missions. While out for a weekend run, Warren received a call from the Payload Operations and Integration Center in Huntsville, Alabama. An astronaut on station, following a prescribed diet for a research study, wanted to swap out a food item. Warren coordinated with her support team and relayed the decision back to orbit—all while continuing her run. The moment, she recalls, underscored the constant, real-time connection between astronauts in space and teams on the ground.

Adam Baker – Checkmate: Space Debris Cleanup

Flight Director Chris Edelen, left, and capsule communicator Jay Marschke discuss their next chess move during a match with NASA astronaut Greg Chamitoff, Expedition 17 flight engineer aboard the space station. NASA/Robert Markowitz

As an aerospace engineer, Adam Baker helped track experiments and spacecraft operations from mission control. Baker remembers when mission control played a live chess match with astronaut Greg Chamitoff during Expedition 17, a moment that showed the unique ways the station connects crews in orbit with people on Earth. His favorite technical project, though, was the RemoveDebris small satellite, deployed from the station in 2018 to test technologies for cleaning up space junk. “Knowing these experiments could one day help keep the orbital environment safe made it even more meaningful,” he said.

Michael McFarlane – Training for Success

Engineers run simulations inside Johnson’s Systems Engineering Simulator during a shuttle-to-station docking simulation. Smiley Pool/Houston Chronicle

As chief of the Simulation and Graphics Branch, Michael McFarlane prepared astronauts for space station assembly missions using high-fidelity simulators. “My greatest memory is seeing the station grow as we successfully executed assembly missions that looked very much like what we analyzed and trained for in our ground-based simulations,” he said.

A Legacy of Ingenuity and Community

Date: 10-31-2023 Location: Bldg 30 MCC, ISS MER Subject: Mission Evaluation Room (MER) Halloween Celebration “MERloween” Photographer: James Blair NASA/James Blair

In the Mission Evaluation Room, engineers not only troubleshoot in real time but also celebrate milestones with traditions like “MERloween,” where controllers dress in space-themed costumes to honor the year’s lessons learned.

NASA’s SpaceX Dragon Freedom spacecraft splashed down in the Gulf of America, off the coast of Tallahassee, Florida, returning Crew-9 to Earth on March 18, 2025. NASA/Keegan Barber

For social media consultant Mark Garcia, sharing the station story with the public has been the highlight of his career. His favorite moment was watching NASA’s SpaceX Crew-9 splash down in 2025, greeted by dolphins in the Gulf of America. “I love writing about the science aboard the station that benefits people on Earth,” he said.

For 25 years, the International Space Station has shown what humanity can accomplish together. The lessons learned aboard will guide Artemis missions to the Moon and future journeys to Mars—ensuring the next 25 years are built on innovation, resilience, and the human spirit.

articles.personality_title: International Space Station marks 25 years of human presence and discovery
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**  
Since November 2, 2000, the International Space Station (ISS) has been continuously inhabited by astronauts from around the world. It serves as a laboratory in space where scientists conduct important experiments and prepare for future missions beyond Earth.

**What happened**  
In 2025, NASA and its partners celebrated 25 years of people living and working together aboard the ISS. Over 290 astronauts from 26 countries have contributed to thousands of experiments. These studies have improved life on Earth and helped plan future missions to the Moon and Mars. The celebration included stories from people who have worked on the station’s life support systems, scientific research, and outreach projects.

**Impact**  
The ISS is unique because it combines science, technology, and human teamwork in space. For example, the life support systems recycle almost all water and air for astronauts, which is crucial for long space trips. Research on the station, like studying the heart in microgravity, helps develop new treatments for diseases on Earth. The station also connects people worldwide through projects like the Spacesuit Art Project, which brought hope to children with cancer.

**What's next step**  
The knowledge gained from the ISS will support NASA’s Artemis missions to the Moon and future journeys to Mars. Continued experiments and improvements in space technology will help astronauts live longer and safer in space. The ISS community will keep sharing discoveries and inspiring people on Earth.

**One-sentence takeaway**  
For 25 years, the International Space Station has been a hub of science, teamwork, and innovation that prepares humanity for exploring beyond Earth.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Station spatiale internationale célèbre 25 ans de présence humaine et de découvertes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**  
Depuis le 2 novembre 2000, la Station spatiale internationale (ISS) est habitée en permanence par des astronautes du monde entier. Elle sert de laboratoire spatial où les scientifiques réalisent des expériences importantes et préparent les futures missions au-delà de la Terre.

**Ce qui s'est passé**  
En 2025, la NASA et ses partenaires ont célébré 25 ans de présence humaine continue à bord de l'ISS. Plus de 290 astronautes de 26 pays ont participé à des milliers d’expériences. Ces recherches ont amélioré la vie sur Terre et aidé à planifier des missions vers la Lune et Mars. La célébration a inclus des témoignages de personnes ayant travaillé sur les systèmes de survie, la recherche scientifique et des projets de sensibilisation.

**Impact**  
L’ISS est unique car elle combine science, technologie et travail d’équipe humain dans l’espace. Par exemple, les systèmes de survie recyclent presque toute l’eau et l’air pour les astronautes, essentiel pour les longs voyages spatiaux. Les études menées, comme celle sur le cœur en impesanteur, aident à développer de nouveaux traitements pour des maladies sur Terre. La station relie aussi les gens à travers des projets comme le projet d’art sur les combinaisons spatiales, qui a apporté de l’espoir aux enfants atteints de cancer.

**Prochaine étape**  
Les connaissances acquises sur l’ISS soutiendront les missions Artemis vers la Lune et les voyages futurs vers Mars. Les expériences et les améliorations technologiques continueront d’aider les astronautes à vivre plus longtemps et en toute sécurité dans l’espace. La communauté de l’ISS continuera de partager ses découvertes et d’inspirer les gens sur Terre.

**En une phrase**  
Depuis 25 ans, la Station spatiale internationale est un centre de science, de travail d’équipe et d’innovation qui prépare l’humanité à explorer au-delà de la Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: La Estación Espacial Internacional celebra 25 años de presencia humana y descubrimientos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**  
Desde el 2 de noviembre de 2000, la Estación Espacial Internacional (EEI) ha estado habitada continuamente por astronautas de todo el mundo. Es un laboratorio en el espacio donde los científicos realizan experimentos importantes y preparan futuras misiones más allá de la Tierra.

**Qué pasó**  
En 2025, la NASA y sus socios celebraron 25 años de presencia humana continua en la EEI. Más de 290 personas de 26 países han participado en miles de experimentos. Estos estudios han mejorado la vida en la Tierra y ayudado a planificar misiones a la Luna y Marte. La celebración incluyó relatos de quienes han trabajado en sistemas de soporte vital, investigación científica y proyectos de divulgación.

**Impacto**  
La EEI es única porque combina ciencia, tecnología y trabajo en equipo humano en el espacio. Por ejemplo, los sistemas de soporte vital reciclan casi toda el agua y el aire para los astronautas, algo vital para viajes largos. La investigación, como el estudio del corazón en microgravedad, ayuda a crear nuevos tratamientos para enfermedades en la Tierra. La estación también conecta a las personas mediante proyectos como el Proyecto de Arte en Trajes Espaciales, que llevó esperanza a niños con cáncer.

**Próximo paso**  
El conocimiento obtenido en la EEI apoyará las misiones Artemis a la Luna y futuros viajes a Marte. Las experimentaciones y mejoras tecnológicas continuarán ayudando a los astronautas a vivir más tiempo y seguros en el espacio. La comunidad de la EEI seguirá compartiendo descubrimientos e inspirando a la gente en la Tierra.

**Conclusión en una frase**  
Durante 25 años, la Estación Espacial Internacional ha sido un centro de ciencia, trabajo en equipo e innovación que prepara a la humanidad para explorar más allá de la Tierra.

articles.title: We’ve found an unexpected structure in the solar system’s Kuiper belt
articles.summary: A newly discovered cluster of objects called the “inner kernel” of the Kuiper belt could teach us about the early history of the solar system – including the movement of Neptune
articles.content:
A newly discovered cluster of objects called the “inner kernel” of the Kuiper belt could teach us about the early history of the solar system – including the movement of Neptune

An artist’s impression of the Kuiper belt ESO/M. Kornmesser

The Kuiper belt, a disc of icy rocks on the outermost edges of the solar system, seems to have more structure than we thought. In 2011, researchers found a cluster of objects there on similar orbits that they dubbed the “kernel” of the Kuiper belt – now, another team has spotted an even more compact cluster of objects that they are calling the “inner kernel”.

The original kernel was found by eye using plots of the orbits of 189 Kuiper belt objects (KBOs). It is about 44 astronomical units from the sun, where one astronomical unit is the distance between the sun and Earth. Since the discovery of the kernel, no additional structures have been found in the Kuiper belt.

That is, until Amir Siraj at Princeton University in New Jersey and his colleagues took on the painstaking task of refining the orbital data from 1650 KBOs and feeding it into an algorithm that searches for clustering and structure. They trained the algorithm to search for the kernel, and then examined the results to see if there were any more structures out there. “The kernel was never found alone – whenever the algorithm found the kernel, it found another group as well,” says Siraj.

The researchers called this newfound cluster the inner kernel because of its location about 43 astronomical units from the sun. All of the objects in the inner kernel have remarkably circular orbits, almost completely in line with the disc of the solar system.

“That kind of orbital calmness is a signal of a very old, undisturbed structure – the kind of structure that can provide clues to the evolution of the solar system, how the giant planets have moved in their orbits, what kind of interstellar environments the solar system has been through, all sorts of things about the early days of the solar system,” says Siraj.

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

It could be particularly enlightening when it comes to learning about Neptune’s migration from the inner solar system, where it is thought to have formed, out to its current position, says David Nesvorný at the Southwest Research Institute in Colorado, one of the discoverers of the original kernel. Nesvorný says it is possible that as Neptune was moving outward, the KBOs that make up the kernel and inner kernel were briefly captured in place through gravitational interactions with the giant planet, causing the clumping that we see now, before being released as Neptune continued on its way.

The Vera C. Rubin Observatory in Chile, which began operations this year, is expected to find many more KBOs than we know of now, which should tell us more about the kernel and inner kernel, as well as whether there are any other as-yet-undiscovered structures on the solar system’s edge. “The more we learn about the architecture of the Kuiper belt, the more we learn about the solar system’s history,” says Siraj.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of a new, compact cluster of objects in the Kuiper belt called the 'inner kernel' provides significant new insights into the early history and evolution of the solar system, including planetary migration. This scientific breakthrough has broad significance for our understanding of space and the solar system's formation, supported by detailed research and data analysis.
articles.personality_title: Scientists discover a new cluster of objects in the Kuiper belt
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Kuiper belt is a ring of icy rocks far beyond Neptune, at the edge of our solar system. In 2011, scientists found a group of objects there called the "kernel," which helped us understand how the solar system formed and changed over time.

**What happened** – A team led by Amir Siraj from Princeton University used new computer methods to study the orbits of 1,650 Kuiper belt objects. They found a smaller, tighter group of objects inside the original kernel. This new cluster is called the "inner kernel" and is located about 43 times the distance from the Earth to the sun.

**Impact** – The objects in the inner kernel move in very smooth, circular paths, showing they have been undisturbed for a very long time. This calm arrangement can reveal how the giant planet Neptune moved from closer to the sun out to its current spot. As Neptune traveled, it may have trapped these objects temporarily, creating the clusters we see today.

**What's next step** – The Vera C. Rubin Observatory in Chile, which started working this year, will discover many more Kuiper belt objects. This will help scientists learn more about the inner kernel, the original kernel, and possibly other hidden groups. Each new discovery brings us closer to understanding the early days of our solar system.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A newly found cluster of objects in the Kuiper belt called the inner kernel offers fresh clues about how Neptune and the solar system formed and changed over billions of years.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques découvrent un nouveau groupe d’objets dans la ceinture de Kuiper
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La ceinture de Kuiper est un anneau de roches glacées situé bien au-delà de Neptune, à la limite de notre système solaire. En 2011, des scientifiques ont trouvé un groupe d’objets appelé le « noyau », qui a aidé à comprendre la formation et l’évolution du système solaire.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe dirigée par Amir Siraj de l’université de Princeton a utilisé de nouvelles méthodes informatiques pour étudier les orbites de 1 650 objets de la ceinture de Kuiper. Ils ont découvert un groupe plus petit et plus compact à l’intérieur du noyau original. Ce nouveau groupe s’appelle le « noyau intérieur » et se trouve à environ 43 fois la distance entre la Terre et le Soleil.

**Impact** – Les objets du noyau intérieur suivent des trajectoires très régulières et circulaires, montrant qu’ils sont restés stables pendant très longtemps. Cette organisation calme peut révéler comment la planète géante Neptune a migré de près du Soleil vers sa position actuelle. En se déplaçant, Neptune a peut-être temporairement piégé ces objets, formant les groupes que nous observons.

**Prochaine étape** – L’observatoire Vera C. Rubin au Chili, qui a commencé ses activités cette année, découvrira beaucoup plus d’objets dans la ceinture de Kuiper. Cela aidera les scientifiques à en apprendre davantage sur le noyau intérieur, le noyau original et d’autres groupes encore inconnus. Chaque nouvelle découverte nous rapproche de la compréhension des débuts du système solaire.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un nouveau groupe d’objets dans la ceinture de Kuiper, appelé le noyau intérieur, apporte des indices précieux sur la formation et l’évolution de Neptune et du système solaire sur des milliards d’années.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren un nuevo grupo de objetos en el cinturón de Kuiper
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El cinturón de Kuiper es un anillo de rocas heladas muy lejos de Neptuno, en el borde de nuestro sistema solar. En 2011, los científicos encontraron un grupo de objetos llamado el "núcleo", que ayudó a entender cómo se formó y cambió el sistema solar.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo liderado por Amir Siraj de la Universidad de Princeton usó nuevos métodos informáticos para estudiar las órbitas de 1,650 objetos del cinturón de Kuiper. Encontraron un grupo más pequeño y compacto dentro del núcleo original. Este nuevo grupo se llama el "núcleo interior" y está a unas 43 veces la distancia entre la Tierra y el sol.

**Impacto** – Los objetos del núcleo interior se mueven en trayectorias muy suaves y circulares, lo que muestra que han estado sin cambios por mucho tiempo. Esta calma puede revelar cómo el planeta gigante Neptuno se movió desde cerca del sol hasta su posición actual. Al moverse, Neptuno pudo haber atrapado temporalmente estos objetos, creando los grupos que vemos hoy.

**Próximos pasos** – El Observatorio Vera C. Rubin en Chile, que empezó a funcionar este año, descubrirá muchos más objetos del cinturón de Kuiper. Esto ayudará a los científicos a aprender más sobre el núcleo interior, el núcleo original, y posiblemente otros grupos escondidos. Cada nuevo hallazgo nos acerca a entender los primeros días del sistema solar.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Un nuevo grupo de objetos en el cinturón de Kuiper llamado núcleo interior ofrece pistas frescas sobre cómo se formaron y cambiaron Neptuno y el sistema solar durante miles de millones de años.
